title: 105_hr3715
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pine River Project Conveyance Act" and includes definitions for clarity. The "Pine River Project Conveyance Act" defines key terms such as "Jurisdictional Map" and "Pine River Project" which includes Vallecito Dam and Reservoir and associated facilities authorized in 1937. The "Repayment Contract" refers to a contract between Reclamation and the Pine River Irrigation District for the Pine River Project. "Reclamation" refers to the Department of the Interior, Bureau of Reclamation, and "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Southern Ute Indian Tribe" or "Tribe" refers to a federally recognized Indian tribe located on the Southern Ute Indian Reservation in Colorado. The term "Pine River Irrigation District" or "District" refers to a political division of the State of Colorado with its principal place of business in Bayfield, Colorado, having rights to water from Vallecito Reservoir. The curr_chunk states ownership of a 5/6 right in the Pine River Project in Colorado. Ownership of a 5/6 right in the Pine River Project in Colorado is transferred. The Secretary authorizes the conveyance of the United States' 5/6 right in the Pine River Project to the Pine River Irrigation District for $492,000. The Sale Price for the Pine River Project will be deposited into the Reclamation Fund. Payment of the Sale Price will end all obligations between the District, Bureau of Indian Affairs, and Reclamation. The Repayment Contract will become null and void after the title transfer. The District is responsible for transaction costs, with 50% credited towards the Sale Price. The Tribe has the option to involve the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The Secretary may convey the Bureau of Indian Affairs' \1/6\ interest in the Pine River Project to the Tribe, along with water rights from Vallecito Reservoir. No additional compensation is required. Conveyance of Reclamation's \5/6\ interest will reduce the Federal dam use charge. The conveyance of Reclamation's \5/6\ interest in the Pine River Project to the Tribe will result in a reduction in the Federal dam use charge assessed under the Federal Power Act for hydropower potential use. SEC. 4. JURISDICTIONAL TRANSFER OF LANDS. In the Jurisdictional Transfer, lands associated with the Pine River Project will be consolidated for the Forest Service and the District. Lands inundated by Vallecito Reservoir will be transferred to Reclamation and the Bureau of Indian Affairs for the Tribe's trust. Following the Jurisdictional Transfer, approximately 230 acres of Project acquired lands above the reservoir water surface elevation level will be transferred to the Forest Service. The Jurisdictional Map and legal descriptions of the transferred lands will be available for public inspection. All lands that become National Forest System lands as a result of the transfer will be administered accordingly. The National Forest System lands within the San Juan National Forest will be administered according to applicable laws. Reclamation withdrawals of land established by Secretarial Orders will be revoked. Perpetual easements will be issued to ensure access for the Pine River Project. The Pine River Project will be maintained by the District with a 5/6 interest in National Forest System lands. Perpetual easements will be issued for public access to Vallecito Reservoir when water levels drop, and for reconstruction and maintenance. The Forest Service will reconstruct, maintain, and operate a road from La Plata County Road No. 501 to National Forest System lands east of the Reservoir. Valid existing rights in land use authorizations will be preserved, with any changes in jurisdiction handled according to applicable law. SEC. 5. LIABILITY. The United States will not be liable for damages related to the conveyance of an undivided \5/6\ right in the Pine River Project, except for negligence prior to the conveyance. This does not increase liability beyond the Federal Tort Claims Act. The Secretary will promptly complete conveyances under section 3 after compliance with environmental laws, satisfaction of the Southern Ute Indian Tribe, amendment of license #3174-001 by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, and submission of a statement on Vallecito Dam's condition. The Bureau of Reclamation is working on an agreement with the District to protect the rights and interests of the Vallecito Dam. The District must submit a plan to manage the Project in a similar manner as before, following Federal and State laws. The Agreement dated March 20, 1998, between the District and residents of Vallecito Reservoir outlines the water use regulations. The Secretary of the Army will develop a flood control plan for Vallecito Dam. If the transfer authorized in section 3 is not completed, a report will be provided to the House and Senate Committees within 18 months. Upon transfer, the District will no longer receive Reclamation benefits as per the Reclamation Act of 1902.
